scenarioDescription:
The TOI-776 Exoplanetary System


Overview

TOI-776 is a star with 0.54 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.54 times its radius. It is located 88.62 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7.8 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

TOI-776 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the TOI-776 system


TOI-776 b

TOI-776 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory, in 2020-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of TOI-776 b is 4.004 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-776 b is 1.850 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 3.4, and a semi-major axis of 0.0652 astronomical units, TOI-776 b could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.


TOI-776 c

TOI-776 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory, in 2020-09, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of TOI-776 c is 5.304 times the mass of Earth. The radius of TOI-776 c is 2.020 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, TOI-776 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system TOI-776, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
name: TOI-776 - System With 2 Exoplanets
